reviewText:
The game features the story of Samantha, a girl who has social anxiety and is laying in her dorm peacefully.... until she notices she's hungry. Very hungry. So, she needs to go to kitchen and try to make a cup of oatmeal, but due to her condition this will not be a simple task.

This short non-kinetic Visual Novel had potential, since it demonstrates accurately how a simple everyday task may be an impossible thing to do for a person with social anxiety. Sadly, it develops too little the main character, which may pass the impression that people with social anxiety are all about their paranoias - and they aren't. A game that addresses such a delicate matter like social anxiety should have done a deep development of their protagonist, in a way she could look more like an individual person rather than a generic character with social anxiety.

Also, after one or two playthroughs, the story gets very repetitive as most of the endings are the same with just a small little variation.

reviewText:
I wasn’t quite sure what to think of The Average Everyday Adventures of Samantha Browne when I first saw it on Steam. The artwork was decent and it was tagged as a visual novel so I decided to give it a try because it was free. When I got into the game I immediately regretted my decision. Playing as Samantha was very annoying and throughout the whole game I wanted to slap her.  All this over a bowl of oatmeal.

When you start the game you’re put into the shoes of a young college student named Samantha Browne who is hungry, however due to her social anxiety she has yet to feed herself and now has to grab a late night bite by going to the kitchen. Simple, right? Wrong. For some reason every choice Samantha makes causes her anxiety, from choosing which flavor of oatmeal to using the microwave. What makes matters worse is her inner monologue comes off as annoying and pretentious, the whole time spent trying to get her to feed herself all I could wonder was how she ever made it to college and how does she plan on making it in the real world. Some of her anxiety I could understand and relate to but most of it just made me roll my eyes, and there really isn’t any story besides her trying to eat.

Controls are easy, you use your mouse to click to make choices as you try to get Samantha fed. You have a anxiety meter at the top right that fills with each choice you make. Some choices only add a little bit while others add more, your goal is get your oatmeal and get back to your room without your anxiety meter filling up. I found the feature interesting, however, I didn’t like how every choice, no matter how small, gave Samantha anxiety. Choosing the wrong oatmeal flavor, waiting for water to boil, trying to use the microwave all made her anxious. My first playthrough I managed to easily feed her and get her back safely but couldn’t not do so without some anxiety building up. If your meter fills all the way up there are a variety of ways to lose; Samantha locks herself out of her room, Samantha doesn’t even leave her room and I imagine starves, Samantha drops her oatmeal and many others.

The artwork in the game is rather simplistic but still visually pleasing, the graphics help put a visual aspect to how anxiety feels. There is also some animation in the game which is a nice touch. I was quite fond of the mug Samantha used to make her oatmeal, it had a cat on it! The music isn’t bad, it fits the game and the sound effects were nice.

While I know everyone has different levels of anxiety and things that trigger it, I really just couldn’t relate to most of what Samantha was going through. I found it dumbfounding how she had such trouble just trying to feed herself, and I’m not even talking about the anxiety she felt having to maybe see people in the kitchen. I imagine some people can find this game relatable which I think is good and I applaud people using video games as a medium to tell emotional stories. Other than it being free and having Steam achievements I find it hard to recommend The Average Everyday Adventures of Samantha Browne, however if you have social anxiety or just want to see what it can be like then give it a shot, it’s very short.

reviewText:
I liked this game! A lot! And I hardly ever use exclamation points!

I thought this was beautifully drawn, the music is pretty, and the story hits close to home... well, honestly, it hit my home dead on, really. I'm quite happy to have played it. :)

It's hard to explain why it pleased me, because it's not just that sense of shared trauma.  There's something a little bit surreal about the experience, which for some reason made me feel the way I feel when I watch my favorite movie, Amélie.  Perhaps it was the music, I'm not sure.  Whatever it was, I just felt good afterwards.

Regarding some of the negative reviews: I think maybe some extroverts might not understand and just consider the story and decisions silly, as they often do about introverts and people with social or generalized anxiety.  If you're an outgoing person, you won't have the same experience people like me have when playing the game, but you still might find it interesting to see what it's like to be us.  It might sound silly or exaggerated, but please know that it's actually accurate.

Two notes:
- As of this writing there is no way to adjust the volume within the game.  I suggest alt-tabbing out of the game, right clicking the speaker icon in the windows taskbar tray, and selecting Mixer.  The game will have its own volume slider, allowing you to adjust it relative to the rest of your system.

When i first saw the reviews of this game, I noticed that there were 2 major criticisms:
1) This is a visual novel, and not a game as the critic views a game to be. I don't like visual novels.
2) This is about a milenial college girl. I don't like milenials.

If these opinions run similar to your own, I imagine you will probably also similarly dislike this game.

To give an alternative series of opinions:
Visual Novels are a game as I define a game, and even if it weren't I still enjoy it as an experience regardless.
Social anxiety is a ♥♥♥♥♥. This game shows examples of this rather well.
University is a nightmare for people with social anxiety. This game also shows this.
Oatmeal as a means to avoid being in public is awesome. This game shows this is certainly the case.
This game is free. I like not having to pay money.
This game has cuteness written all over it. I like cute things.
The game is a short simple game. I like games that get to the point and don't overstay their welcome.
Forgetting keys is the worst.
I really want to watch that show that Sam is watching, She clearly has great taste in TV.
Greatest spoon ever since Broken Age.
The art style reminds me of bee and puppycat. I love that show and i love this visual novel.
I like both gameplay heavy games and games with minimalist gameplay.

If any of the opinions sound similar to your own opinion, there's a good chance you will enjoy this game.

reviewText:
I just played this game.
Then I read over the other reviews, positive as negative.

I can see some of the negative points, e.g. the main character not knowing how a electric kettle works (how did she get into college?) but other than that, I thought the game was fine.

It is not meant to portray every social anxiety and every person suffering from it. It is not meant as a psychological rulebook or a scientific paper. It's just a nice game about a girl who has mild social anxiety and lives in a dorm where the kitchen is shared with a lot of strangers.

I cannot see depression portrayed in this game (which was what other comments hinted). Social anxiety likes to comes hand in hand with depression but doesn't have to.

Regarding the game: You have to go through a lot of decisions for the goal of having some hot oatmeal. Most of the good decisions are obvious, which is like in real life. At least for me. I mostly know what I am supposed to do but feel pressured and nervous and just wanna go back into hiding. I believe this is what the writer(s) wanted to show the audience.

If you have half an hour to spare for a funny little VN, I can recommend this one.

reviewText:
Beautiful visuals for a visual novel, although the idea is a good one to explore I do not think it was executed as effectively as the creator was hoping.

It is a short game to play for those interested in understanding visual novels and seeing what the medium calls for. This VN falls short in the writing, the part that sealed the deal for me was doing the actual oatmeal in the microwave. A tedious and underwelming experience that could have been pushed farther to explore more of the thought process of an anxious individual. The picking the spoon sequence does not work thematically and falls flat.

Perspective is another weak point, having additional thoughts or perhaps more of an internal dialogue that showcased what the protagonist thinks the characters in the kitchen are going to react, perhaps through a cute animated sequence, would have really driven home more ways to showcase the anxiety and ruminating that happens with people with anxiety.

The anxiety could have been pushed further in the second half of the VN.

Solid art style, I can see Reimena Yee moving onto grander projects. It's a good artist debut into the indie dev world.

A recommend for people who are new to game development or Visual Novel making and needing to expand their repertoire of experiences outside of the industry standards.

Don't stop making games.

reviewText:
TL;DR - short, fun, sort of though provoking, oatmeal, keys...

The Average Everyday Adventures of Samantha Browne puts you in the role of the titular Samantha Browne - kind of.
Okay, first off, this game isn't very long. If you feel like having a cup of oatmeal, you could probably leave it standing next to you and it would be just the right temperature to eat by the time you are done with a playthrough.
That being said, it is a fun little game. Sure, it's not an epic quest to slay dragons, but it is an adventure in its own right - a quest of delicious oatmeal to ward off starvation for another day.
The sole goal of the game is leaving your room, making some oatmeal and getting back safely. But the long and perilous journey is where you see the strong side of the game. By the way of Samantha's thoughts you are presented with some of the things people with social anxiety might go through every day.
If you make it to the very end: congratulations, you might just have learned something, or gained a little insight - and be it only insight into how to make oatmeal.
One last thing: Don't forget your keys!

It might seem like just going down the hall to make yourself food isn't a big deal at all, but that's the point: to some people, socially anxious people, it can be. I give the people who made this game lots of kudos, and I would love to see more Average Everyday Adventures in the future.

reviewText:
As a game, it's... not bad. As a narrative about social anxiety, it's reasonable; a lot better than many depictions found in games and television. It gives a basic rundown and is sympathetic to the character.

I can certainly empathize; as a kid who grew up hiding assignment papers and computer screens from supervising teachers, I have some idea of how irrationally cautious and/or anxious everyday things can be to people with anxiety disorders. To this day, I still occasionally avoid kitchens when there are other people in them. I also tend to choose my seats in cafeterias carefully so I can either see anybody approaching, or hide myself eating, depending on whether I'm more self-conscious or anxious that day. I also don't fix hair or apply deodorant in washrooms if anybody else is present. Sometimes people will go great lengths to avoid ordinary facts of life.

Honestly, while I appreciate the depiction of the character, the game itself defies one of the unspoken rules of interaction: if the player gets a game over, it should be their fault. In this game, many of the ways to fail come from seemingly unrelated decisions. Your first playthrough of the game is blind and you will probably fail by no fault of your own. In games that follow this rule like Dark Souls, failing is a consequence of poor decisions. In this game, seemingly innocuous and ordinary decisions carry severe consequences. I would say that this is the major failing of the game.

As far as this goes, I'm inclined not to recommend it as a game. It's a cutesy story to experience for 10 minutes, but navigating the multiple endings isn't all that rewarding when most of them are failures. This game is an obstacle course of torture dressed up in a vibrant oatmeal-coloured package. For the price of free, by all means play it, but it's about as interesting as one might find a new meme to be.

Before this review becomes longer than the game, I bid Adieu.

EDIT: And why in the world does this need a 2 GHz processor!? That's like saying you need a Ferrari to drive to your Grandma's home 5 blocks away...

reviewText:
If you've ever wanted to roleplay as a disabled college girl, now is your chance!
'visual-novel'-style gameplay without the novel or gameplay elements.
Good luck figuring out how to actually finish it, there is not distinct cause-and-effect between the story and the options you select, you're basically stuck either getting lucky, or trying every option systematically until you finish it.
Very minimal depth, I felt it made an attempt to go for a 'cutsey' aesthetic, but failed.

I'm worried for the future of storytelling and media in general.
